dt: {bc}a plant (such as a rose, blackberry, or greenbrier) having a usually woody and thorny or prickly stem

dt.t: … head up an almost invisible trail along the left bank, through young pines and {wi}briars{/wi}.
… threading his way with perfect skill between tree-trunks, jumping over bush and {wi}briar{/wi} and the smaller streams …
… volunteers methodically searching through the {wi}briar{/wi} and trees …

dt: {bc}a branch or twig of a briar

dt.t: With my pair of brush cutters that I always carried I cut away enough of the long {wi}briars{/wi} to provide an opening for me to sit comfortably in.

shortdef: a plant (such as a rose, blackberry, or greenbrier) having a usually woody and thorny or prickly stem
a branch or twig of a briar

et: Middle English {it}brer, brere,{/it} going back to Old English {it}brēr, brǣr,{/it} of uncertain origin

The noun {it}briar{/it} belongs to a small set of words in which Middle English {it}ę̄ {/it} has been raised to {it}ī,{/it} whence [ai] in present-day English. These words are all, with the exception of {it}briar,{/it} of French origin: {et_link|friar|friar}, {et_link|quire:1|quire:1}, {et_link|choir:1|choir:1}, {et_link|contrive|contrive}, {et_link|umpire:1|umpire:1}, {et_link|dice|die:2}. See hypothesized explanations of this change in E. J. Dobson, {it}English Pronunciation 1500-1700,{/it} 2nd edition, vol. 2, pp. 655-58.
shortdef: a plant (such as a rose, blackberry, or greenbrier) having a usually woody and thorny or prickly stem
a branch or twig of a briar
